snippet: “Garden at Sainte-Adresse,” Monet’s 1867 painting of a sun-dappled seaside, has belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1967. For the next six months, anyway, it has a new companion.
abstract: Carol Vogel Inside Art column; Oracle chief executive and co-founder Lawrence J Ellison lends Metropolitan Museum of Art Monet’s Adolphe Monet Reading in a Garden, which will join Monet's 1867 Garden at Sainte-Adresse, which museum has owned since 1967, for six months; twenty-five early works on paper by Brice Marden are being displayed in newly-renovated space in Chelsea; Peter Brant is opening Julian Schnabel retrospective at his Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn; new gallery is opening at 550 West 21st Street in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: “Garden at Sainte-Adresse,” Monet’s 1867 painting of a sun-dappled seaside, has belonged to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1967. For the next six months, anyway, it has a new companion.

headline.main: Monet Seaside Gardens, Blooming Side by Side
headline.print_headline:
Monet Seaside Gardens,
Blooming Side by Side
